The project entails the implementation of various technologies and measures aimed at reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Key components of the project include monitoring and reporting protocols, sampling-based monitoring surveys with quality assurance and quality control procedures, and the distribution of improved cookstoves (ICS) to beneficiary households. These measures are expected to contribute significantly to the reduction of GHG emissions.

The project is situated within the Republic of India, geographically. By leveraging improved cookstoves and other strategies, the project aims to generate substantial GHG emission reductions. It is projected to achieve an average annual reduction of 2,297,154 tCO2e, with a total reduction of 16,080,078 tCO2e over a 7-year crediting period.

Prior to the project's initiation, stakeholder consultation sessions were conducted to discuss various aspects of the project activity. Topics covered included the technologies and measures to be employed, the baseline scenario, grievance mechanisms, Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) benefits, and the transfer of credit ownership. Stakeholders were provided with a non-technical project summary and given a 30-day window to offer feedback.

In terms of estimated reductions and removals, the project anticipates an average annual GHG emission reduction of 2,297,154 tCO2e. Across the 7-year crediting period, the total GHG emission reduction is expected to reach 16,080,078 tCO2e.

This summary encapsulates the essence of the project, outlining its technological components, location, expected GHG emission reductions, pre-project scenario, and projected reductions over the project's duration.
